history.content:
I took the FPGA lab last semester. I have not taken the ASIC lab though. 

Starting off with the main difference between FPGA and ASIC, an FPGA is basically a giant microcontroller whose purpose you can keep reprogramming. An ASIC though is custom-built (although you'll never get it fabricated in lab or anything like that), so ASICs have longer verification cycles and time to market. You'll also be coding in the same language (Verilog) in both labs, but there will be different projects. Basically, it's whatever floats your boat, because bottom-line is that both labs will eat up a lot of your time. Don't take them lightly.

So this page accurately summarizes the difference between FPGAs and ASICS: http://www.xilinx.com/fpga/asic.htm, but I took the FPGA lab last semester. I didn't take the ASIC lab though.

Basically, it's whatever floats your boat, because bottom-line is that both labs will eat up a lot of your time. Don't take them lightly.

Please see @400 for clarification from the instructors.
Is there any real difference between the two? Why should I take one over the other?
history.subject: What is the difference between ASIC Lab (EECS 151LA) and FPGA Lab (EECS 151LB).
